evidence.text: The Plaintiffs in this lawsuit are indigent Virginia residents who have suffered indefinite suspension of their driver’s licenses for failure to pay court costs and fines that they could not afford.

Hundreds of thousands of people have lost their licenses simply because they are too poor to pay, effectively depriving them of reliable, lawful transportation necessary to get to and from work, take children to school, keep medical appointments, care for ill or disabled family members, or, paradoxically, to meet their financial obligations to the courts.

extracted.value: Indigent Virginia residents with driver's licenses suspended for failure to pay court costs they could not afford, leading to loss of transportation necessary for employment, medical care, and meeting financial obligations

evidence.text: On May 20, 2013, the Defendant suspended his driver’s license for nonpayment of the $501.00 in costs and fines imposed on April 15, 2013.
The Defendant did not offer Mr. Stinnie an opportunity to demonstrate that he was unable to pay either before or after suspending his license.

extracted.value: Damian Stinnie's license suspended May 20, 2013, for $501 unpaid costs after failing to pay traffic fines from April 2013 convictions, without inquiry into his financial circumstances

evidence.text: On or about May 6, 2016, the Defendant suspended Ms. Moore’s driver’s license for nonpayment of the $232 in costs imposed on April 7, 2016.

Ms. Moore does not currently have a job. Ms. Moore cannot take in-home CNA placements in Chesterfield County, because she cannot get to the clients’ homes anymore based on her decision not to drive and be convicted again for driving on a suspended license, rooted in her inability to pay.

extracted.value: Demetrice Moore's license suspended May 6, 2016, for $232 unpaid costs after driving while suspended conviction, causing loss of in-home CNA job requiring driving

evidence.text: Without a driver’s license, Mr. Taylor has been unable to obtain employment because of difficulties getting to and from job interviews outside of Richmond and because he cannot guarantee prospective employers that he will have reliable transportation if hired.

Mr. Taylor applied for a position at an AT&T service location as a customer representative. The position would have been compensated with an annual salary and comprehensive employee benefits. However, Mr. Taylor could not find a way to travel to the interview in Colonial Heights, Virginia, and he was not hired.

extracted.value: Robert Taylor's license suspended multiple times for unpaid court costs, causing inability to secure employment due to lack of transportation to job interviews
